content.title: THE ENERGY TRANSITION IN CONTEXT
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

The current global energy transition marks a pivotal departure from historical shifts, driven not merely by technological advancement but by the existential urgency of climate change. Unlike past transitions—such as the move from biomass to fossil fuels during the Industrial Revolution—today’s shift demands rapid decarbonization, systemic societal transformation, and a reimagining of economic growth paradigms. At its heart, this transition is defined by the imperative to limit global warming to 1.5°C under the Paris Agreement, requiring unprecedented collaboration, innovation, and equity across nations. This lesson explores how the modern energy transition diverges from its predecessors, emphasizing climate mitigation, net-zero frameworks, and the integration of policy and technology. It examines the role of international mechanisms like Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and the challenges of bridging gaps between pledges and implementation. Through insights from the IPCC and IEA, the lesson underscores the tension between urgent climate action and slow progress, particularly in balancing the responsibilities of developed and developing nations under the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy transition
concepts.body: The energy transition refers to the global shift from fossil fuel-based energy systems to renewable and sustainable energy sources, aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions and combating climate change.

concepts.title: net zero
concepts.body: Net zero refers to the balance between the amount of greenhouse gas emissions produced and the amount removed from the atmosphere, resulting in no net increase in emissions.

concepts.title: carbon neutrality
concepts.body: Carbon neutrality is the state of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by balancing the amount of carbon released with an equivalent amount of carbon offset or removed from the atmosphere.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Another energy transition.... but the context -and concept- has evolved

content.text: Part 1 Overview

The world has gone through energy transitions before. For example, the industrial revolution's shift from the prevailing wood and biomass energy sources to coal, oil, and more recently, natural gas. Historically, transitions have marked pivotal moments in societal development and global economic systems - they represent significant structural shifts in both supply and consumption patterns. However, the present energy transition presents some important differences from the previous.
5 key differences of the present energy transition
Climate change mitigation is key

"Energy transition" now encompasses climate change mitigation efforts, emphasizing the imperative to transition to sustainable energy sources and reduce the energy intensity of our residential, commercial, and industrial energy use.
Net Zero as a guiding framework

This transition is driven by the recognition that GHG emissions must be significantly reduced, with any remaining emissions offset, necessitating the replacement of fossil fuels within a net-zero emissions framework.
Not just technology but also policy

Beyond mere technological advancements, this energy transition also entails a reorientation of energy policy - such as shifting from centralized to distributed generation, increasing energy efficiency, and ensuring no one is left behind.
It needs to involve everyone, now
The current energy transition demands unprecedented speed and scale, impacting all populations and all sectors of society.
To navigate this transition successfully, some fundamental shifts are required

Emphasizing the risks posed by continued reliance on fossil fuels, particularly their impact on climate change, which underscores the need for a shift toward sustainable and low-carbon energy solutions. Reforming governance structures to move beyond arrangements focusing on partial solutions - and instead adopting holistic and systemic approaches necessary to drive change at the required pace and scale. Embracing an interconnected perspective and integrated approach to energy systems.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: The Paris Agreement and Global Decarbonization Efforts

content.text: THE PARIS AGREEMENT AND GLOBAL DECARBONIZATION EFFORTS

The impacts of a warming planet are more evident than ever. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)—a United Nations body tasked with assessing climate science—warns in its Sixth Assessment Report that failing to drastically reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions will severely harm human health, biodiversity, and lead to irreversible ecosystem losses much sooner than anticipated. The path forward is clear: we must immediately and drastically cut emissions while accelerating the transition to a clean energy economy. In 2015, the world united under the Paris Agreement, a legally binding international treaty adopted at COP21. Its goal is to limit global warming to “well below 2°C,” ideally 1.5°C, compared to pre-industrial levels. To achieve this, countries commit to reaching global peaking of GHG emissions as soon as possible and achieving climate neutrality by 2050. Key tools for meeting these targets are Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and Long-Term Strategies (LTS). NDCs are 5-year national climate action plans, while LTS outline 20- to 30-year roadmaps for systemic transformations. These frameworks prioritize scaling up renewable energy (RE) and energy efficiency (EE)—cornerstones of the energy transition—by setting binding targets for solar, wind, and other clean technologies, alongside reducing energy demand through innovation and policy.
THE PARIS AGREEMENT AND GLOBAL DECARBONIZATION EFFORTS

To accelerate progress, countries and companies are adopting net-zero targets, which aim to balance GHG emissions with removals, achieving “net-zero” emissions by mid-century. While carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) and direct air capture (DAC) play roles in offsetting emissions from hard-to-abate sectors like heavy industry, comprehensive strategies must also integrate nature-based solutions. These include reforestation, wetland restoration, and sustainable land management, which enhance carbon sinks while protecting biodiversity. Critically, addressing emissions from land use, forestry, and agriculture—which account for nearly 25% of global GHG emissions—is essential to achieving net-zero goals. Practices such as regenerative farming, reducing deforestation, and improving soil health are pivotal, even though these sectors fall outside direct energy system reforms.
THE ENERGY TRANSITION IN CONTEXT

The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), established in 1992, is a global treaty ratified by all UN member states to address climate change. Its core objective is to stabilize greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere to prevent dangerous human interference with the climate system. Under the UNFCCC, developed countries are recognized as having contributed the largest share of historical emissions, with developing countries’ per capita emissions remaining relatively low. However, the Paris Agreement establishes that all countries must work to limit emissions, guided by the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities (CBDR). This framework places greater mitigation obligations on developed nations, including providing climate finance to support developing countries. Despite these commitments, recent data underscores slow progress. The IEA’s World Energy Outlook 2024 (WEO 2024) highlights that even under the Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS), current efforts fall short of aligning with the 1.5°C target. The report stresses that existing policies lack both the credibility and urgency needed to close this gap, particularly as global emissions continue to rise. Emerging technologies to offset emissions show potential but remain insufficiently scaled to meet demand.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: The renewable energy transition is driven by climate urgency, unlike past energy shifts.
takeaways.description: Unlike previous transitions, the move to renewables is fueled by the imperative to mitigate climate change and act swiftly. This urgency demands rapid adoption of clean energy technologies and policies to reduce carbon emissions and avoid catastrophic environmental impacts.

takeaways.title: A just energy transition prioritizes social inclusion and equity.
takeaways.description: Ensuring fairness and creating opportunities for vulnerable groups is central to the just energy transition. By addressing social inequalities and preventing marginalized communities from being left behind, the transition aims to build a more inclusive and equitable energy future.

takeaways.title: The just energy transition requires a paradigm shift in governance and risk perception.
takeaways.description: Transitioning to renewables necessitates rethinking governance structures and adopting holistic, systemic approaches. Emphasizing the risks of fossil fuel dependency and embracing interconnected energy systems will enable more effective and integrated solutions for a sustainable future.
